(the Company) is an artificial intelligence (AI)\ntechnology and consumer electronics holding company with two primary business units  SemiCab and Singing Machine. SemiCab is an\nAI-enabled software logistics business operated through the Companys subsidiary, SemiCab Holdings, LLC. Singing Machine is a home\nkaraoke consumer products business that designs and distributes karaoke products globally to retailers and ecommerce partners through\nthe Companys subsidiary, The Singing Machine Company, Inc.\n\n\n\nThe\nCompanys operations include its wholly-owned subsidiaries, SMC Logistics, Inc., a California corporation (SMCL),\nSMC-Music, Inc., a Florida corporation (SMCM), SMC (HK) Limited, a Hong Kong company (SMH), The Singing Machine\nCompany, Inc., a Delaware corporation (SMC), MICS Hospitality Holdings, Inc., a Delaware corporation (MICS Hospitality),\nMICS Hospitality Management, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company (MICS Hospitality Management), and MICS Nomad, LLC,\na Delaware limited liability company (MICS NY), and its\n80\n%-owned subsidiaries, SemiCab Holdings, LLC, a Nevada limited\nliability company (SemiCab Holdings) and SMCB Solutions Private Limited, an Indian Company (SMCB).\n\n\n\nEffective\nSeptember 5, 2024, the Companys Certificate of Incorporation was amended to change the name of the Company from The Singing\nMachine Company, Inc. to Algorhythm Holdings, Inc.\n\n\n\nOn\nJanuary 13, 2025,\nthe Companys stockholders voted to authorize the Companys board of directors to effect a reverse stock\nsplit of the Companys outstanding shares of common stock at a specific ratio within a range of 1-for-10 to a maximum of 1-for-250\nand to amend the Companys certificate of incorporation to increase the number of authorized common stock from 100,000,000 to 800,000,000\nshares. On January 14, 2025, the Companys board of directors approved a reverse stock split of 1-for-200 ratio and approved the\nfiling of a certificate of amendment to the Companys certificate of incorporation to effect the reverse stock split and to increase\nthe Companys authorized shares of common stock from 100,000,000 to 800,000,000. The reverse stock split took effect on February\n10, 2025. All current and prior year balances have been adjusted to reflect the reverse stock split.\n\n\n\nOn\nMay 2, 2025, the Company and SemiCab Holdings entered into an equity purchase agreement with SemiCab Inc. pursuant to which: (i) SemiCab\nHoldings purchased\n9,999\nshares of the issued and outstanding equity shares, Rs.\n10\npar value, of SMCB, representing 99.99% of the issued\nand outstanding equity shares of SMCB, for $\n1,750,000\n, the payment of which was evidenced by the issuance of a promissory note by the\nCompany to the SemiCab, Inc., and (ii) the Company purchased the\n20\n% membership interest in SemiCab Holdings then held by SemiCab, Inc.\nfor aggregate consideration consisting of\n119,742\nshares of the Companys common stock. The acquisition was completed on May 2,\n2025.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n6\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\nNOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and\n2023\n\n\n', '_attributes': {'escape': 'true', 'id': 'Fact000757', 'name': 'us-gaap:NatureOfOperations'}, '_context': {'_contextref': 'From2025-01-01to2025-06-30', 'context_entity_identifier': '0000923601', 'context_period_startdate': '2025-01-01', 'context_period_enddate': '2025-06-30'}}

{'_val': 'Note\n2 \nLiquidity, Going Concern and Management Plans\n\n\n\nGoing\nConcern Analysis\n\n\n\nAs\nof June 30, 2025, the Companys cash balance was $\n1,134,000\n. This will not be sufficient to fund the Companys planned operations\nfor at least one year after the date the condensed consolidated financial statements are issued. The Company has a recent history of\nrecurring operating losses and decreases in working capital. These factors create substantial doubt about the Companys ability\nto continue as a going concern for at least one year after the date that the Companys condensed consolidated financial statements\nare issued.\n\n\n\nThe\ncondensed consolidated financial statements do not include any adjustments that might be necessary if the Company is unable to continue\nas a going concern. Accordingly, the condensed consolidated financial statements have been prepared under the assumption that the Company\nwill continue as a going concern and that the realization of assets and satisfaction of liabilities and commitments will continue in\nthe ordinary course of business.\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany plans to finance operations by obtaining additional capital through external sources of financing. It may attempt to obtain additional\ncapital through the sale of equity securities or the issuance of debt securities. The Company has not made arrangements to obtain additional\ncapital and can provide no assurance that additional financing will be available in an amount or on terms acceptable to the Company,\nif at all.\n\n\n\nIn\nmaking this assessment, management performed a comprehensive analysis of the Companys current circumstances including its financial\nposition, cash flow and outflow forecasts, and obligations and debts. Although management has a recent history of successful capital\nraises, the analysis used to determine the Companys ability to continue as a going concern does not include cash resources outside\nthe Companys direct control that management expects to be available within the next 12 months.\n\n\n', '_attributes': {'escape': 'true', 'id': 'Fact000772', 'name': 'us-gaap:SubstantialDoubtAboutGoingConcernTextBlock'}, '_context': {'_contextref': 'From2025-01-01to2025-06-30', 'context_entity_identifier': '0000923601', 'context_period_startdate': '2025-01-01', 'context_period_enddate': '2025-06-30'}}

{'_val': 'Note\n3 \nSummary of Significant Accounting Policies\n\n\n\nBasis\nof Presentation\n\n\n\nThe\naccompanying unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements for the three and six months ended June 30, 2025 and 2024 have been\nprepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (U.S. GAAP) applicable\nto interim financial information and the requirements of Form 10-Q and Article 8 of Regulation S-X of the SEC. Accordingly, they do not\ninclude all of the information and disclosures required by US GAAP for complete consolidated financial statements.\n\n\n\nIn\nthe opinion of management, the condensed consolidated financial statements include all adjustments (consisting of normal recurring accruals)\nnecessary for the fair presentation of the condensed consolidated financial position and the condensed consolidated results of operations.\nThe condensed consolidated results of operations for the periods presented are not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected\nfor the full year. The condensed consolidated balance sheet as of June 30, 2025 and condensed financial statement information for the\nthree and six months ended June 30, 2025 and 2024 are unaudited, whereas the condensed consolidated balance sheet as of December 31,\n2024 is derived from the audited consolidated balance sheet as of that date. The condensed consolidated financial statements and notes\nhereto should be read in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements and notes thereto included in the Companys annual\nreport on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2024. There have been no changes to the Companys significant accounting policies\nas disclosed on the Companys annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2024.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n7\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\nNOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and\n2023\n\n\n\nSegment\nReporting\n\n\n\nPursuant\nto Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Accounting Standards Codification (ASC) Topic 280,\nSegment\nReporting\n(ASC 280), the Companys Chief Executive Officer serves as the Companys Chief Operating Decision\nMaker (CODM) for the purposes of ASC 280. The CODM concluded that the Company operates two reportable segments.\nOne\nsegment\nconsists of its SemiCab business and the other segment consists of its Singing Machine business. The CODM manages the Companys\noperations and business separately for each operating segment and uses net loss to allocate resources, making operating decisions and\nevaluating financial performance. The CODM also uses net loss, along with non-financial inputs and qualitative information, to evaluate\nthe Companys performance, establish compensation, monitor budget versus actual results, and decide the level of investment in\nvarious operating activities and other capital allocation activities.\nSee Note 14  Segment Information and Revenue Disaggregation\n Segment Information\n.\n\n\n\nRecent\nAccounting Pronouncements\n\n\n\nIn\nDecember 2023, the\nFASB\nissued\nAccounting Standards Update (ASU) 2023-09,\nIncome Taxes (Topic 740): Improvements to Income Tax Disclosures\n.\nASU 2023-09 is intended to enhance the usefulness of income tax disclosures by requiring entities to disclose specific rate reconciliations,\nthe amount of income taxes separated by federal and individual tax jurisdictions, and the amount of income (loss) from continuing operations\nbefore income tax expense (benefit) disaggregated among federal, state and foreign. ASU 2023-09 is effective for the Company for its\nfiscal year beginning January 1, 2025. The adoption of ASU 2023-09 did not have a material impact on the\nCompanys consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.\n\n\n\nIn\nNovember 2024, the FASB issued ASU 2024-03,\nIncome Statement  Reporting Comprehensive IncomeExpense Disaggregation Disclosures\n(Subtopic 220-40)\n. This ASU requires disclosure on an annual and interim basis, in the notes to the financial statements, of disaggregated\ninformation about specific categories underlying certain income statement expense line items. The guidance is effective for annual periods\nbeginning after December 15, 2026, and interim periods with annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2027, on a retrospective\nbasis. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of this standard on its consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.\n\n\n\nIn\nNovember 2024, the FASB issued ASU 2024-04,\nDebt  Debt with Conversion and Other Options (Subtopic 470-20)\n. This ASU clarifies\nthe requirements for determining whether certain settlements of convertible debt instruments should be accounted for as an induced conversion.\nASU 2024-04 is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2025, and interim reporting periods within those annual reporting\nperiods. Early adoption is permitted for all entities that have adopted the amendments in ASU 2020-06. Adoption can be on a prospective\nor retrospective basis. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of this standard on its consolidated financial statements and\nrelated disclosures.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n8\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\nNOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and\n2023\n\n\n\nIn\nMay 2025, the FASB issued ASU 2025-03,\nBusiness Combinations (Topic 805) and Consolidation (Topic 810).\nThis ASU provides that\na reporting entity involved in a business combination effected primarily by the exchange of equity interests must consider the factors\nin ASC 805-10-55-12 through 55-15 to determine which entity is the accounting acquirer regardless of whether the legal acquiree is a\nVariable Interest Entity (VIE). The amendments in ASU 2025-03 must be applied prospectively to any business combination\nthat occurs after the initial adoption date. ASU 2025-03 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2026, including interim\nperiods within those fiscal years. Early adoption is permitted. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of this standard on its\nconsolidated financial statements and related disclosures.\n\n\n\nIn\nMay 2025, the FASB issued ASU 2025-04,\nCompensation  Stock Compensation (Topic 718) and Revenue from Contracts with Customers\n(Topic 606)\n, which clarifies the guidance in both ASC 718 and ASC 606 on the accounting for share-based payment awards that are granted\nby an entity as consideration payable to its customer. The ASU is intended to reduce diversity in practice and improve existing guidance,\nprimarily by revising the definition of a performance condition and eliminating a forfeiture policy election for service\nconditions associated with share-based consideration payable to a customer. In addition, the ASU clarifies that the guidance in ASC 606\non the variable consideration constraint does not apply to share-based consideration payable to a customer regardless of whether\nan awards grant date has occurred (as determined under ASC 718). ASU 2025-04 is effective for fiscal years beginning after\nDecember 15, 2026, including interim periods within those fiscal years. Early adoption is permitted. The Company is currently evaluating\nthe impact of this standard on its consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.\n\n\n', '_attributes': {'escape': 'true', 'id': 'Fact000776', 'name': 'us-gaap:SignificantAccountingPoliciesTextBlock'}, '_context': {'_contextref': 'From2025-01-01to2025-06-30', 'context_entity_identifier': '0000923601', 'context_period_startdate': '2025-01-01', 'context_period_enddate': '2025-06-30'}}

{'_val': 'Note\n4 \nVariable Interest Entities\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany determined that SMCB was a VIE because the Company provided financial support to SMCB in the form of a loan agreement to fund\nSMCBs operations. The Company further determined that it was not the primary beneficiary of SMCB because the Company did not have\nthe power to direct or control SMCBs significant activities related to its business. Accordingly, the Company had not consolidated\nSMCBs results of operations and financial position in its condensed consolidated financial statements prior to May 2, 2025.\n\n\n\nOn\nMay 2, 2025, the Company and SemiCab Holdings acquired\n99.99\n% of the equity shares of SMCB from SemiCab, Inc. As a result, on May 2,\n2025, the Company consolidated SMCBs results of operations and financial position in its condensed consolidated financial statements.\nA discussion of this transaction is set forth herein in\nNote 17  Acquisition of SMCB\n\n\n\n\nF-\n9\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\nNOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and\n2023\n\n\n', '_attributes': {'escape': 'true', 'id': 'Fact000786', 'name': 'us-gaap:VariableInterestEntityDisclosureTextBlock'}, '_context': {'_contextref': 'From2025-01-01to2025-06-30', 'context_entity_identifier': '0000923601', 'context_period_startdate': '2025-01-01', 'context_period_enddate': '2025-06-30'}}

{'_val': 'Note\n7 \nCredit Facilities and Other Financing Arrangements\n\n\n\nOxford\nCredit Facility\n\n\n\nOn\nMarch 28, 2024, the Company entered into a loan agreement and related revolving credit note with Oxford Commercial Finance (Oxford).\nThe agreement was for a two-year term and established a secured asset-backed revolving credit facility that was comprised of a maximum\n$\n2,000,000\nrevolving credit facility. Availability under the credit facility was determined monthly by a borrowing base comprised of\na percentage of eligible accounts receivable of the borrowers. The Companys obligations under the credit agreement were secured\nby a continuing security interest in all property of each Loan Party, subject to certain excluded collateral. As of June 30, 2024, there\nwas no availability under the Credit Facility as there were no eligible accounts receivable.\n\n\n\nOn\nOctober 17, 2024, the Company terminated the loan agreement and note and paid Oxford a termination fee of $\n40,000\n. As of the date of\ntermination, the Company had no outstanding amounts owed to Oxford.\n\n\n\nAgile\nCapital Merchant Cash Advance\n\n\n\nIn\nconnection with the acquisition of SemiCab, Inc.s business, the Company assumed a merchant cash advance that was payable to Agile\nCapital Funding, LLC that had been incurred under a financing agreement that SemiCab, Inc. had entered into on March 22, 2024. The initial\namount borrowed was $\n315,000\n, with net proceeds to SemiCab, Inc. in the amount of $\n300,000\n. Repayment terms consisted of weekly payments\nin the amount of $\n16,200\nfor 28 weeks for a total repayment of $\n453,600\n. The effective interest rate for the borrowings was\n15\n% per year.\nAs of December 31, 2024, the merchant cash advance had been repaid in full.\n\n\n\nCedar\nAdvance Merchant Cash Advance\n\n\n\nIn\nconnection with the acquisition of SemiCab, Inc.s business, the Company assumed a merchant cash advance that was payable to Cedar\nAdvance, LLC that had been incurred under a financing agreement that SemiCab, Inc. had entered into on May 8, 2024. The initial amount\nborrowed was $\n215,000\n, with net proceeds to SemiCab, Inc. in the amount of $\n204,300\n. Repayment terms consisted of weekly payments in\nthe amount of $\n11,100\nfor 28 weeks for a total repayment of $\n312,000\n. {'_val': 'Note\n8 \nCommitments and Contingencies\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany is subject to claims, suits and other proceedings from time to time in the ordinary course of business that could result in fines,\ncivil penalties, or other adverse consequences. In accordance with the provisions of ASC Topic 450,\nContingencies,\nthe Company\nrecords a liability when it believes that it is probable that a loss has been incurred and the amount can be reasonably estimated. If\nthe Company determines that it is probable that a loss has been incurred and the loss or range of loss can be estimated, the Company\ndiscloses the estimated amount of the loss. The Company evaluates developments in its legal matters that could affect the amount of liability\nthat has been previously accrued and makes adjustments as appropriate. Significant judgment is required to determine both likelihood\nof there being and the estimated amount of a loss related to such matters.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n12\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\nNOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and\n2023\n\n\n\nEfficient\nCapital Labs Settlement Agreement\n\n\n\nOn\nMay 18, 2023, SemiCab, Inc. entered into an installment business loan agreement with Efficient Capital Labs, Inc. (ECL)\npursuant to which SemiCab, Inc. borrowed the principal amount of $\n1,000,000\n. Repayments were originally scheduled to begin in June 2023\nin equal installments of $\n91,667\nfor 13 months with an effective interest rate of\n17.97\n%. The loan had a maturity date of May 17, 2024.\nOn May 18, 2024, SemiCab, Inc. defaulted on the loan for non-payment.\n\n\n\nOn\nMay 18, 2024, SemiCab, Inc. entered into a settlement agreement with ECL pursuant to which SemiCab, Inc. agreed to pay ECL $\n946,666\nas\nfollows: (i) $\n25,000\non or before May 20, 2024; (ii) $\n75,000\non or before June 3, 2024; and (iii) $\n84,666\non or before the first business\nday of each of the following 10 calendar months starting on July 1, 2024.\n\n\n\nIn\nconnection with the acquisition of SemiCab, Inc.s business, the Company assumed this settlement liability. The final payment of\nthe settlement was made during the six months ended June 30, 2025. Accordingly, there was\nno\nunpaid balance at June 30, 2025. As of December\n31, 2024, the remaining unpaid balance of the settlement was $\n325,000\nand was included as a component of accrued expenses on the Companys\ncondensed consolidated balance sheets.\n\n\n\nDerivative\nLitigation\n\n\n\nOn\nDecember 21, 2023, Ault Lending, LLC (Ault Lending), a wholly-owned subsidiary of Ault Alliance, Inc., a former shareholder\nof the Company, filed a derivative shareholder action in Delaware Chancery Court against the Company, its board of directors, Stingray\nGroup, LLC (Stingray Group) and\nRegalia Ventures, LLC (Regalia Ventures)\nfor alleged breach of fiduciary duty in approving a recent above-market private placement equity transaction. The complaint alleged that\nthe Company and its board of directors followed an inadequate process in evaluating the private placement transaction that the Company\ncompleted in November 2023 and that the Company and its board of directors entered into the transaction with an intent to dilute Aults\nownership stake in the Company. Ault Lending was seeking the following relief from the court: (i) declarations that the defendant directors\nbreached their fiduciary duties; and that Stingray Group and\nRegalia Ventures\naided and\nabetted those breaches; (ii) rescission of the Companys sale of shares to Stingray Group and\nRegalia\nVentures\n; and (iii) damages and attorneys fees. On April 30, 2025, Ault Lending filed a motion with the court requesting\nthat the claims be dismissed without prejudice and on that same date, the court approved the dismissal of the claims without prejudice.\n\n\n\nOAC\nFlatiron & OAC Adelphi Litigation\n\n\n\nOn\nAugust 23, 2023, MICS NY entered into an Agreement of Lease (the Lease Agreement) with OAC 111 Flatiron, LLC and OAC Adelphi,\nLLC (the Landlord), pursuant to which MICS NY agreed to lease approximately\n10,000\n\nsquare feet of ground floor retail space\nand a portion of the basement underneath the ground floor retail space in the property located at 111 West 24\nth\nStreet, New\nYork, New York (the Premises).\n\n\n\n\nF-\n13\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\nNOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and\n2023\n\n\n\n\nDuring\nthe year ended December 31, 2024, the Company abandoned its plans to continue use of the leased space and exercised its early termination\nprovision of the Lease Agreement which was not accepted by the Landlord. Due to the abandonment of the lease, all assets related to the\nlease were impaired. Assets including security deposits, rent deposits and right of use assets of approximately $\n3,878,000\nwere written\noff during the year ended December 31, 2024.\n\n\n\nOn\nJuly 26, 2024, the Landlord filed a civil action in the Supreme Court of the State of New York against MICS NY and the Company (the\nDefendants) for alleged breach of lease, seeking monetary damages including unpaid rent, future unpaid rent, and other expenses\nrelated to the lease. The complaint alleged the Defendants breached the lease in various material respects.\n\n\n\nOn\nSeptember 25, 2024, the Company entered into a settlement agreement for a full release and dismissal of the complaint within five business\ndays of the Companys payment of $\n250,000\n. Pursuant to the settlement agreement, the Company made the first payment of $\n150,000\non September 25, 2024 and a final payment of $\n100,000\non October 25, 2024. The remaining lease liability was written off upon settlement,\nresulting in a loss upon termination of the lease of $\n4,000\n, net of the write off of the related lease asset discussed above. On October\n29, 2024, the Landlord filed a discontinuance with prejudice.\n\n\n\nBlue\nYonder Liability\n\n\n\nPursuant\nto the asset purchase agreement with SemiCab, Inc., the Company assumed a judgement against SemiCab, Inc. regarding damages resulting\nfrom contract breach for IT subscription-based services. On March 28, 2020, SemiCab, Inc. entered into a service contract and agreement\nwith Blue Yonder, Inc. (Blue Yonder) for certain IT subscription-based services. The original term of the agreement was\nfor three years, at a price of $\n100,000\nper year, for a total of $\n300,000\n.\n\n\n\nOn\nJune 21, 2023, Blue Yonder filed a lawsuit claiming damages in the amount of $\n275,000\nwith the Maricopa County Superior Court in Arizona.\nThe suit was found in favor of Blue Yonder in the amount of $\n509,119\n, subject to two separate milestone payments that would otherwise\ndeem the entire balance due satisfied if either milestone payment is made by the Company. The first milestone payment for $\n175,000\nand\nwas due on July 1, 2024 and was not made. In the event this payment is made, the remaining settlement shall be deemed satisfied. If this\npayment is not made, the Company shall owe a total of $\n225,000\nby October 1, 2024. In the event this payment is made, the remaining settlement\nshall be deemed satisfied. If neither payment is made, Blue Yonder shall be entitled to execute the full $\n509,119\nbeginning January 1,\n2025. As of the date of this filing, none of the scheduled payments have been made. A liability of $\n509,119\nhas been recorded as a component\nof accrued expenses on the accompanying condensed consolidated balance sheets.\n\n\n\nOn\nFebruary 11, 2025, Blue Yonder filed a civil action in the Superior Court of the State of Arizona against the Company for breach of contract\nand to enforce a stipulated judgment entered against SemiCab, Inc. in connection with the liabilities related to Blue Yonder that the\nCompany assumed when it acquired SemiCab, Inc.s business. Blue Yonder alleges that, because the Company assumed these liabilities,\nBlue Yonder can enforce the judgment against the Company. The judgement was in the amount of $\n509,119\n. On August 1, 2025, the Company\nfiled an answer to the complaint and counterclaims against Blue Yonder for breach of contract. The outcome of this matter is uncertain.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n14\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\nNOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and\n2023\n\n\n', '_attributes': {'escape': 'true', 'id': 'Fact000955', 'name': 'us-gaap:CommitmentsAndContingenciesDisclosureTextBlock'}, '_context': {'_contextref': 'From2025-01-01to2025-06-30', 'context_entity_identifier': '0000923601', 'context_period_startdate': '2025-01-01', 'context_period_enddate': '2025-06-30'}}

The Company\nreceived aggregate gross proceeds upon the closing of the offering of approximately $\n9,000,000\n, before deducting placement agents\nfees and other offering expenses.\n\n\n\nThe\nSeries A and B warrants\n\nwere exercisable only upon receipt\nof such shareholder approval as may be required by the applicable rules and regulations of the Nasdaq Stock Market, LLC (the Nasdaq)\nto permit the exercise of the Series A and B warrants\n. The Series A and B warrants include an exercise\nprice adjustment feature upon shareholder approval, whereby the exercise price will adjust to the greater of the lowest daily volume\nweighted average price during the reset period or the floor price, which was $\n6.84\nper share, with a proportional increase in the number\nof warrant shares.\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany assessed the Series A and B warrants under ASC 480 and ASC 815 and determined that the Series A and B warrants needed to be classified\nas\nliabilities\nas they did not meet the requirements to be considered indexed to the Companys own stock, due to: (a) the adjustment to the exercise\nprice tied to shareholder approval, and (b) the potential change in the settlement amount of the Series B warrants upon an alternative\ncashless exercise election. Additionally, the Company concluded at issuance that it would not have sufficient authorized and available\nshares of common stock to settle the Series A and B warrants. See\nNote 12  Derivative Liability\n.\n\n\n\nOn\nJanuary 13, 2025, the Companys stockholders approved the issuance of the Series A and B warrants, at which time all of the Series\nA and B warrants became exercisable. {'_val': 'Note\n14 \nSegment Information and Revenue Disaggregation\n\n\n\nSegment\nInformation\n\n\n\nPursuant\nto ASC 280, the Companys Chief Executive Officer serves as the Companys Chief Operating Decision Maker (CODM)\nfor the purposes of ASC 280. The CODM concluded that the Company operates two reportable segments. One segment consists of its Singing\nMachine business and the other segment consists of its SemiCab business. The CODM manages the Companys operations and business\nseparately for each operating segment and uses net sales and net loss to allocate resources, making operating decisions and evaluating\nfinancial performance. The CODM also uses net sales and net loss, along with non-financial inputs and qualitative information, to evaluate\nthe Companys performance, establish compensation, monitor budget versus actual results, and decide the level of investment in\nvarious operating activities and other capital allocation activities.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n20\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\nNOTES TO {'_val': 'Notes\n15 \nConcentrations, Risks and Uncertainties\n\n\n\nBank\nLiquidity and Financial Stability\n\n\n\nAt\ntimes, the Company maintains cash in United States bank accounts that are more than the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation insured\namounts. The Company maintains cash balances in foreign financial institutions. The Company regularly monitors the financial stability\nof this financial institution and believes that it is not exposed to any significant credit risk in cash and cash equivalents. However,\nin March and April 2023, certain U.S. government banking regulators took steps to intervene in the operations of certain financial institutions\ndue to liquidity concerns, which caused general heightened uncertainties in financial markets. While these events have not had a material\ndirect impact on the Companys operations, if further liquidity and financial stability concerns arise with respect to banks and\nfinancial institutions, either nationally or in specific regions, the Companys ability to access cash or enter into new financing\narrangements may be threatened, which could have a material adverse effect on its business, financial condition and results of operations.\n\n\n\nU.S.\nTrade Policies\n\n\n\nU.S.\ngovernment administration and members of the U.S. Congress have recently implemented significant changes in U.S. trade policy and taken\ncertain actions that are impacting the Companys business, including imposing tariffs on certain goods imported into the United\nStates. Some of these changes have triggered retaliatory actions by affected countries and may result in trade wars and\nincreased costs for goods imported into the United States. All of the Companys products are manufactured and imported from China\nand the Company sells its products in Canada and other countries. The implementation of tariffs has resulted in an increase in the cost\nof the Companys products. If the Company is unable to mitigate these increased costs through price increases, it may experience\nlower sales which would negatively impact its revenue, gross profit margin and results of operations.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n22\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\nNOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and\n2023\n\n\n\nRevenue\nConcentration\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany derives a majority of its revenue from sales by retailers of its home karaoke consumer products in North America sales of its\nAI-enabled software logistics services in India. {'_val': 'Note\n16 \nRelated Party Transactions\n\n\n\nStingray\nGroup Subscription Payments\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany has a music subscription sharing agreement with Stingray Group. For the three and six months ended June 30, 2025, the Company\nreceived music subscription revenue of $\n187,000\nand $\n451,000\n, respectively, from Stingray Group. For the three and six months ended June\n30, 2024, the Company received music subscription revenue of $\n109,000\nand $\n349,000\n, respectively, from Stingray Group. As of June 30,\n2025 and December 31, 2024, the Company had $\n124,000\nand $\n212,000\n, respectively, due from Stingray Group for music subscription reimbursement.\n\n\n\nSMCB\n\n\n\nVIE\nAnalysis\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany determined that SMCB, which was a subsidiary of SemiCab, Inc. prior to the SemiCab Holdings acquisition of\n99.99\n% of the\nequity shares of SMCB on May 2, 2025, was a VIE as the Company provides financial support to SMCB. While not contractually obligated,\nSMCB currently relies on the Companys reimbursement of certain costs under an intercompany services agreement (MSA)\nwhereby SMCB agrees to provide IT software development services to SemiCab, Inc. In exchange, under the MSA, the Company grants intellectual\nproperty rights to SMCB to use the software platform in India. Compensation for services is invoiced and paid on a monthly or quarterly\nbasis as agreed by both parties, with rates subject to periodic review and revision. The agreement is for a term of two years ending\non April 1, 2025 and automatically renews for additional 12-month periods unless prior notice is given by the terminating party. The\nagreement automatically renewed for an additional 12-month period on April 1, 2025. As a result of this relationship and the financial\nsupport provided by the Company to SMCB under the loan agreement described below to fund SMCBs operations, SMCB has been determined\nto be a VIE prior to May 2, 2025.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n23\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\nNOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and\n2023\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany further determined that it was not the primary beneficiary of SMCB because the Company did not have the power to direct or control\nSMCBs significant activities related to its business. Accordingly, the Company has not consolidated SMCBs results of operations\nand financial position in its condensed consolidated financial statements.\n\n\n\nPursuant\nto the terms of the asset purchase agreement that the Company entered into on June 11, 2024, the Company entered into an option agreement\nthat granted SemiCab Holdings the right to acquire all of the issued and outstanding equity securities of SMCB for\n1,605\nshares of the\nCompanys common stock. The Company did not exercise this right and the option agreement expired on August 31, 2024.\n\n\n\nLoan\nAgreement\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany is a party to a loan agreement with SMCB dated March 22, 2024. Under the loan agreement, the Company agreed to loan up to $\n2,500,000\nto SMCB. The loans are anticipated to be made in tranches. Disbursements of any tranches are fully at the discretion of the Company.\nEach tranche has a repayment period of five years. The loans can be repaid at any time prior to the five-year maturity date without penalty.\nInterest on the loans accrues at a rate of six percent per year and is payable quarterly.\n\n\n\nAt\nDecember 31, 2024, a total of $\n1,140,000\nwas outstanding under the loan agreement. During the period beginning January 1, 2025 and ending\nMay 2, 2025, the date the Company acquired\n99.99\n% of the equity shares of SMCB, the Company made advances to SMCB in the amount of $\n1,172,000\n.\nDuring the same period, SMCB charged $\n304,000\nfor services to the Company that were performed under the MSA, which charges offset amounts\ndue under the loan with SMCB. As a result, as of May 2, 2025, a total of $\n2,008,000\nof loans were outstanding under the loan agreement,\nand a total of $\n492,000\nremained available for future borrowings under the loan agreement as of May 2, 2025. As of May 2, 2025, SMCB\nhad not made any interest payments due under the loan agreement. As a result, the loans were in default as of May 2, 2025.\n\n\n\nOn\nMay 2, 2025, the loan payable of $\n2,008,000\nof SMCB and the loan receivable of $\n2,008,000\nof the Company were eliminated in consolidation.\nAs a result, no such loans payable and loans receivable were outstanding on the Companys condensed consolidated balance sheet\nat June 30, 2025. Also on May 2, 2025, revenue generated by SMCB for services performed by SMCB under the MSA of $\n304,000\n, and expenses\nfor the Company for services performed by SMCB under the MSA of $\n304,000\n, during the period commencing January 1, 2025 and ending May\n2, 2025 were eliminated in consolidation on May 2, 2025. As a result, no such revenue and expenses were reflected on the Companys\ncondensed consolidated statements of operations for the three and six months ended June 30, 2025.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n24\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\nNOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and\n2023\n\n\n', '_attributes': {'escape': 'true', 'id': 'Fact001603', 'name': 'us-gaap:RelatedPartyTransactionsDisclosureTextBlock'}, '_context': {'_contextref': 'From2025-01-01to2025-06-30', 'context_entity_identifier': '0000923601', 'context_period_startdate': '2025-01-01', 'context_period_enddate': '2025-06-30'}}

{'_val': 'Note\n2 \nLiquidity, Going Concern and Management Plans\n\n\n\nAs\nof December 31, 2024, the Companys cash balance was $\n7,550,000\n. This will not be sufficient to fund its planned operations for\nat least one year after the date the consolidated financial statements are issued. The Company has a recent history of recurring operating\nlosses and decreases in working capital. These factors create substantial doubt about the Companys ability to continue as a going\nconcern for at least one year after the date that the Companys audited consolidated financial statements are issued.\n\n\n\nThe\nconsolidated financial statements do not include any adjustments that might be necessary if the Company is unable to continue as a going\nconcern. Accordingly, the consolidated financial statements have been prepared under the assumption that the Company will continue as\na going concern and that the realization of assets and satisfaction of liabilities and commitments will continue in the ordinary course\nof business.\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany plans to finance operations by obtaining additional capital through external sources of financing. It may attempt to obtain additional\ncapital through the sale of equity securities or the issuance of debt securities. The Company has not made arrangements to obtain additional\ncapital and can provide no assurance that additional financing will be available in an amount or on terms acceptable to the Company,\nif at all.\n\n\n\nIn\nmaking this assessment, management performed a comprehensive analysis of the Companys current circumstances including its financial\nposition, cash flow and outflow forecasts, and obligations and debts. Although management has a recent history of successful capital\nraises, the analysis used to determine the Companys ability to continue as a going concern does not include cash resources outside\nthe Companys direct control that management expects to be available within the next 12 months.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n32\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNOTES\nTO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and 2023\n\n\n', '_attributes': {'escape': 'true', 'id': 'Fact002250', 'name': 'us-gaap:SubstantialDoubtAboutGoingConcernTextBlock'}, '_context': {'_contextref': 'From2024-01-012024-12-31_srt_ScenarioPreviouslyReportedMember', 'context_entity_identifier': '0000923601', 'context_entity_segment_explicitmember': 'srt:ScenarioPreviouslyReportedMember', 'context_period_startdate': '2024-01-01', 'context_period_enddate': '2024-12-31'}}

{'_val': '7,550,000', '_attributes': {'name': 'us-gaap:Cash', 'id': 'Fact002252', 'format': 'ixt:numdotdecimal', 'decimals': '0', 'unitref': 'USD'}, '_context': {'_contextref': 'AsOf2024-12-31_srt_ScenarioPreviouslyReportedMember', 'context_entity_identifier': '0000923601', 'context_entity_segment_explicitmember': 'srt:ScenarioPreviouslyReportedMember', 'context_period_instant': '2024-12-31'}}

{'_val': 'Note\n3 \nSummary of Significant Accounting Policies\n\n\n\nBasis\nof Presentation\n\n\n\nThe\naccompanying consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the\nUnited States of America (GAAP).\n\n\n\nPrinciples\nof Consolidation\n\n\n\nThe\naccompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company, its wholly-owned subsidiaries SMCL, SMCM, SMH, Singing\nMachine, MICS Hospitality, MICS, MICS Hospitality Management, MICS NY, and its eighty percent (\n80\n%)-owned subsidiary, SemiCab\nHoldings. All intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation for all periods presented.\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany evaluates its business relationships with related parties to identify potential Variable Interest Entities (VIEs)\nunder the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Accounting Standards Codification (ASC) 810,\nConsolidation\n.\nThe Company will consolidate any VIE in which it is deemed to be the primary beneficiary of the VIE. The Company will be deemed to be\nthe primary beneficiary of the VIE if the Company has a controlling financial interest in the VIE. A controlling financial interest has\nthe following characteristics: (i) the power to direct the activities of the VIE that most significantly impact its economic performance;\nand (ii) the obligation to absorb losses of the VIE that could be significant to the VIE or the right to receive benefits from the VIE\nthat could be significant to the VIE. If both characteristics are met and, then the Company will consolidate that VIE into its consolidated\nfinancial statements.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n33\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNOTES\nTO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and 2023\n\n\n\nAs\nprescribed by ASC 810, if the Company holds a variable interest in an entity that is a VIE, but the Company is not the entitys primary\nbeneficiary, then the Company must disclose the methodology (e.g., significant judgments and assumptions made) that it used to determine\nthat it is not the primary beneficiary of the VIE. Additional information required includes information about the types of involvement\nconsidered significant, and those considered in the determination of whether the reporting entity is the primary beneficiary.\n\n\n\nFurthermore,\nif the Company provides or intends to provide financial or other support, whether explicitly or implicitly, to the VIE when not contractually\nrequired to, the Company must disclose the type and amount of the support along with the primary reasons for providing the support. Both\nqualitative and quantitative information about the Companys involvement with the VIE must be disclosed, including the nature,\npurpose, size, and activities of the VIE and how the VIE is financed.\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany determined that SMCB Solutions Private Limited, an Indian Company (SMCB), is a VIE because the Company\nprovides financial support to SMCB in the form of a loan agreement to fund SMCBs operations. The Company further determined that it is not the primary beneficiary of SMCB because the\nCompany does not have the power to direct or control SMCBs significant activities related to its business. Accordingly, the\nCompany has not consolidated SMCBs results of operations and financial position in its consolidated financial\nstatements.\n\n\n\nReclassification\nof Prior Periods Presentation\n\n\n\nCertain\nprior period amounts have been reclassified for consistency with the current year presentation. These reclassifications had no effect\non the reported results of operations.\n\n\n\nUse\nof Estimates\n\n\n\nThe\npreparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions. These estimates and\nassumptions affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses. Actual results could differ materially from these\nestimates. Estimates are assessed each period and updated to reflect current information. Significant estimates include allowance for\ncredit losses, provision for excess and obsolete inventory, reserve for sales returns, co-op promotion incentives, accruals relating\nto litigation, goodwill, share-based compensation expense and warrant liability.\n\n\n\nSegment\nReporting\n\n\n\nPursuant\nto Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Accounting Standards Codification (ASC) Topic 280,\nSegment\nReporting\n(ASC 280), the Companys Chief Executive Officer serves as the Companys Chief Operating Decision\nMaker (CODM) for the purposes of ASC 280. The CODM concluded that the Company operates two reportable segments.\nOne\nsegment\nconsists of its SemiCab business and the other segment consists of its Singing Machine business. The CODM manages the Companys\noperations and business separately for each operating segment and uses net loss to allocate resources, making operating\ndecisions and evaluating financial performance. The CODM also uses net loss, along with non-financial inputs and qualitative\ninformation, to evaluate the Companys performance, establish compensation, monitor budget versus actual results, and decide the\nlevel of investment in various operating activities and other capital allocation activities.\nSee Note 15  Segment Information\nand Revenue Disaggregation  Segment Information\n.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n34\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNOTES\nTO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and 2023\n\n\n\nAccounts\nReceivable and Allowances for Expected Credit Losses\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany recognizes credit losses in accordance with Accounting Standards Update 2016-13,\nFinancial Instruments  Credit Losses\n(Topic 326)\n.\nThe Company recognizes an allowance\nfor credit losses at the time a receivable is recorded based on its estimate of expected credit losses and adjusts this estimate over\nthe life of the receivable as needed. The Company evaluates specific identified risks and the aggregation and risk characteristics of\na receivable pool and develops loss rates that reflect historical collections, current forecasts of future economic conditions over the\ntime horizon the Company is exposed to credit risk, and payment terms or conditions that may materially affect future forecasts. As needed,\namounts are written-off when determined to be uncollectible.\n\n\n\nInventory\n\n\n\nInventory\nis comprised primarily of electronic karaoke equipment, microphones, and accessories, and are stated at the lower of cost or net realizable\nvalue, as determined using the first in, first out method. The Company reduces inventory on hand to its net realizable value on an item-by-item\nbasis when it is apparent that the expected realizable value of an inventory item falls below its original cost. A charge to cost of\nsales results when the estimated net realizable value of specific inventory items declines below cost. In addition, the Company reports\nan estimated amount for the net realizable value of expected future inventory returns (returns asset) related to the Companys\ndefective allowance, overstock, and warranty policies.  Substantially\nall of the Companys inventory consists of finished goods.\n\n\n\nProperty\nand Equipment, Net\n\n\n\nProperty\nand equipment are stated at cost, less accumulated depreciation. Expenditures for repairs and maintenance are charged to expense as incurred.\nDepreciation is provided for in amounts sufficient to relate the cost of depreciable assets to their estimated useful lives using straight-line\nmethods.\n\n\n\nLeases\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany determines if an arrangement contains a lease at the inception of a contract. Right-of-use assets represent the Companys\nright to use an underlying asset for the lease term and lease liabilities represent the Companys obligation to make lease payments\narising from the lease. Right-of-use assets and lease liabilities are recognized at the commencement date. The liability is equal to\nthe present value of the remaining minimum lease payments. The asset is based on the liability, subject to certain adjustments. Operating\nleases result in straight-line expense (similar to operating leases under the prior accounting standard) while finance leases result\nin a front-loaded expense pattern (similar to capital leases under the prior accounting standard). As the interest rate implicit in the\nCompanys operating leases is not readily determinable, the Company utilizes its incremental borrowing rate to discount the lease\npayments. The Company utilizes the implicit rate for its finance leases.\n\n\n\n\n\nBusiness\nCombinations\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany accounts for business combinations using the acquisition method of accounting in accordance with ASC Topic 805,\nBusiness Combinations.\nThe Company allocates the purchase price of an acquired business to the tangible and intangible assets acquired and liabilities assumed\nbased upon their estimated fair values on the acquisition date. Any excess of the purchase price over the fair value of the net assets\nacquired is recorded as goodwill. The purchase price allocation process requires management to make significant estimates and assumptions\nat the acquisition date with respect to intangible assets. The allocation of the consideration transferred in certain cases may be subject\nto revision based on the final determination of fair values during the measurement period, which may be up to one year from the acquisition\ndate. Direct transaction costs associated with the business combination are expensed as incurred. The Company includes the results of\noperations of the business that it has acquired in its consolidated results prospectively from the date of acquisition.\n\n\n\nGoodwill\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany evaluates its goodwill for impairment in accordance with FASB Accounting Standards Update (ASU) 350,\nIntangibles\n Goodwill and Other\n. Goodwill is recorded when the purchase price paid for an acquisition exceeds the estimated fair value\nof the net identified tangible and intangible assets acquired. The Company tests the recorded amount of goodwill for impairment on an\nannual basis on December 31 or more frequently if there are indicators that the carrying amount of goodwill exceeds its carried value.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n35\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNOTES\nTO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and 2023\n\n\n\nLong\nLived and Intangible Assets\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany reviews long-lived assets and intangible assets for impairment in accordance with ASC Topic 360,\nProperty, Plant and Equipment\n(ASC 360).\nThe Company reviews long-lived assets and intangible assets for impairment\nwhenever events or changes in business circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the assets might not be recoverable.\nFactors that the Company considers in deciding when to perform an impairment review include significant underperformance of the\nbusiness in relation to expectations, significant negative industry or economic trends, and significant changes or planned changes\nin the use of the assets. If an impairment review is performed to evaluate a long-lived asset or intangible asset for\nrecoverability, the Company compares forecasts of undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the use and eventual disposition\nof the asset to its carrying value. An impairment loss is recognized when the estimated undiscounted future cash flows expected to\nresult from the use of the asset is less than its carrying amount. The impairment loss would be based on the excess of the carrying\nvalue of the impaired asset over its fair value, determined based on discounted cash flows.\n\n\n\nThe Company had\nno\nimpairment\nloss related to long-lived assets or intangible assets for the year ended December 31, 2024 or the nine months ended December 31,\n2023.\n\n\n\nFair\nValue Measurements\n\n\n\nIn\naccordance with ASC 820,\nFair Value Measurements and Disclosures\n, fair value is defined as the exit price, or the amount that\nwould be received for the sale of an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants as of\nthe measurement date.\n\n\n\nThe\nguidance also establishes a hierarchy for inputs used in measuring fair value that maximizes the use of observable inputs and minimizes\nthe use of unobservable inputs by requiring that the most observable inputs be used when available. Observable inputs include those that\nmarket participants would use in valuing the asset or liability and are developed based on market data obtained from sources independent\nof the Company. Unobservable inputs are inputs that reflect the Companys assumptions about the factors that market participants\nwould use in valuing the asset or liability. The guidance establishes three levels of inputs that may be used to measure fair value:\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel\n                                            1: Quoted market prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel\n                                            2: Inputs other than Level 1 that are observable, either directly or indirectly, such as\n                                            quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities; quoted prices in markets that are not active;\n                                            or model-derived valuations. All significant inputs used in the Companys valuations\n                                            are observable or can be derived principally from or corroborated with observable market\n                                            data for substantially the full term of the assets or liabilities. Level 2 inputs also include\n                                            quoted prices that were adjusted for security-specific restrictions which are compared to\n                                            output from internally developed models such as a discounted cash flow model.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel\n                                            3: Unobservable inputs that are supported by little or no market activity and that are significant\n                                            to the fair value of the assets or liabilities.\n\n\n\nThe\ncarrying amounts of financial instruments carried at cost, including cash, accounts receivables and accounts receivable\n related party, trade payables advances and notes payables and notes payable  related party approximate their fair value\ndue to the short-term maturities of such instruments.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n36\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNOTES\nTO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and 2023\n\n\n\nThe\ncategorization of a financial instrument within the valuation hierarchy is based upon the lowest level of input that is significant to\nthe fair value measurement.\n\n\n\nWarrants\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany accounts for warrants as either equity-classified or liability-classified instruments based on an assessment of the warrants\nspecific terms and applicable authoritative guidance in FASB ASC 480, Distinguishing Liabilities from Equity (ASC 480)\nand ASC 815, Derivatives and Hedging (ASC 815). The assessment considers whether the warrants are freestanding financial\ninstruments pursuant to ASC 480, meet the definition of a liability pursuant to ASC 480, and whether the warrants meet all of the requirements\nfor equity classification under ASC 815, including whether the warrants are indexed to the Companys own ordinary shares and whether\nthe warrant holders could potentially require net cash settlement in a circumstance outside of the Companys control,\namong other conditions for equity classification. Finally, the Company determines if the warrants meet the definition of a derivative\nbased on their contractual terms. This assessment, which requires the use of professional judgment, is conducted at the time of warrant\nissuance, as of each subsequent quarterly period end date while the warrants are outstanding and at interim dates if circumstances warrant\nsuch analysis.\n\n\n\nFor\nissued or modified warrants that meet all of the criteria for equity classification, the warrants are required to be recorded as a component\nof additional paid-in capital at the time of issuance. For issued or modified warrants that do not meet all the criteria for equity classification,\nthe warrants are required to be recorded at their initial fair value on the date of issuance, and at each balance sheet date thereafter.\nChanges in the estimated fair value of the liability classified warrants are recognized as a non-cash gain or loss on the consolidated\nstatements of operations. The Company also evaluates if changes in contractual terms or other considerations would result in the reclassification\nof outstanding warrants from liabilities to stockholders equity (or vice versa).\n\n\n\nRevenue\nRecognition\n\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany recognizes revenue in accordance with ASC 606,\nRevenue from Contracts with Customers\n. All revenue is generated from contracts\nwith customers. The Company recognizes revenue when the control of the goods sold is transferred to the customer, in an amount, referred\nto as the transaction price, that reflects the consideration to which the Company expected to be entitled in exchange for those goods.\nThe Company determines revenue recognition utilizing the following five steps: (i) identification of the contract with a customer; (ii)\nidentification of the performance obligations in the contract (promised goods or services that are distinct); (iii) determination of\nthe transaction price; (iv) allocation of the transaction price to the performance obligations; and (v) recognition of revenue when,\nor as, the Company transfers control of the product or service for each performance obligation.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n37\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNOTES\nTO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and 2023\n\n\n\nThe\nCompanys performance obligations are established when a customer submits a purchase order notification and the Company accepts\nthe order. The Company identifies performance obligations as the delivery of the requested product or service in appropriate quantities\nand to the location specified in the customers contract and/or purchase order. Revenue from sales of products is recognized at\na point in time when the Company transfers control to the customer, typically at the time when the product is delivered or shipped, at\nwhich time, title passes to the customer and there are no further performance obligations with regard to the product.\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany selectively participates in retailers co-op promotion incentives to maximize sales of the Companys products on\nthe retail floor and to assist in developing consumer awareness of new product launches by providing marketing fund allowances to its\ncustomers. As these co-op promotion initiatives are not a distinct good or service and the Company cannot reasonably estimate the fair\nvalue of the benefit it receives from these arrangements, the cost of these allowances at the time they are offered to the customers\nis recorded as a reduction to net sales. Co-op promotion incentives were $\n2,059,000\nduring the year ended December 31, 2024 and $\n2,648,000\nduring the nine months ended December 31, 2023.\n\n\n\nThe\nCompanys contracts with customers consist of one performance obligation, which is the sale of its products. The Companys\ncontracts have no financing elements. Payment terms are generally less than 120 days and have no further contract asset or liability\nobligations once control of goods is transferred to the customer. Revenue is recorded in the amount of consideration the Company expects\nto receive for the sale of these goods.\n\n\n\nCosts\nincurred in fulfilling contracts with customers include administrative costs associated with the procurement of goods are included in\ngeneral and administrative expenses, in-bound freight costs are included in the cost of goods sold and accrued sales representative commissions\nare included in selling expenses in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations as the Companys underlying customer agreements are\nless than one year.\n\n\n\nReserve\nfor Sales Returns and Returns Asset\n\n\n\nWhile\nthe Company has no overstock return privileges in its vendor agreements with its customers, it does accept defective returns, warranty\nexchanges and overstock from seasonal customers. The Company estimates the sales value of goods to be returned from its allowance programs\nfor goods returned from the customer for various reasons, whereby a reserve for sales returns is recorded based on historic return amounts,\nspecific events as identified and management estimates. The Companys reserve for sales returns was $\n3,355,000\nand $\n3,390,000\nas\nof December 31, 2024 and 2023, respectively. The Company estimates the net realizable value of these expected future sales returns. The\nnet realizable value of these estimated returns is classified as return assets as part of current assets on the Companys consolidated\nfinancial statements. The Companys return assets were $\n1,621,000\nand $\n1,919,000\nas of December 31, 2024 and 2023, respectively.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n38\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNOTES\nTO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and 2023\n\n\n\nShipping\nand Handling Costs\n\n\n\nShipping\nand handling activities are performed before the customer obtains control of the goods sold to them and are considered activities to\nfulfill the Companys promise to transfer the goods. Shipping and handling expenses were $\n592,000\nand $\n561,000\nfor the year ended\nDecember 31, 2024 and the nine months ended December 31, 2023, respectively. These expenses are classified as a component of selling\nexpenses in the Companys consolidated statements of operations.\n\n\n\nShare-Based\nCompensation\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany has granted stock options, warrants, restricted stock awards and restricted stock units to employees, non-employee consultants\nand non-employee members of its board of directors. The Company also has an equity incentive plan that provides for the issuance of equity\nincentive awards, such as stock options, warrants, stock appreciation rights, stock awards, restricted stock, stock units, performance\nawards and other stock or cash-based awards to the Companys employees, officers, directors, consultants, agents, advisors and\nindependent contractors.\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany measures the compensation cost associated with all share-based payments based on grant date fair values. The fair value of each\nstock option and stock purchase right is estimated on the date of grant using an option pricing model that meets certain requirements.\nThe Company generally uses the Black-Scholes option pricing model to estimate the fair value of its stock options and stock purchase\nrights. The determination of the fair value of share-based payment awards utilizing the Black-Scholes model is affected by the Companys\nstock price and several assumptions, including expected volatility, expected term, risk-free interest rate and expected dividends.\n\n\n\nFor\ngrants of stock options, the Company uses a blend of historical and implied volatility for traded options on its stock to estimate the\nexpected volatility assumption required in the Black-Scholes model. The Companys use of blended volatility estimates in computing\nthe expected volatility assumption for stock options is based on its belief that while the implied volatility is representative of expected\nfuture volatility, the historical volatility over the expected term of the award is also an indicator of expected future volatility.\nThe Company utilizes a blended volatility estimate that consists of implied volatility and historical volatility in order to estimate\nthe expected volatility assumption of the Black-Scholes model.\n\n\n\nThe\nexpected term of stock options granted is estimated using historical experience. The risk-free interest rate assumption is based on observed\ninterest rates appropriate for the expected terms of the Companys stock options and stock purchase rights. The dividend yield\nassumption is based on the Companys history and expectation of no dividend payouts. The Company estimates forfeitures at the time\nof grant and revises these estimates, if necessary, in subsequent periods if actual forfeitures differ from those estimates. The Company\nestimates its forfeiture rate assumption for all types of share-based compensation awards based on historical forfeiture rates related\nto each category of award.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n39\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNOTES\nTO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and 2023\n\n\n\n\nCompensation\ncosts associated with grants of restricted stock awards and restricted stock units are measured at fair value, which has historically\nbeen the closing price of the Companys common stock on the date of grant.\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany recognizes share-based compensation expense over the requisite service period of each individual award, which generally equals\nthe vesting period, using the straight-line method for awards that contain only service conditions. For awards that contain performance\nconditions, the Company recognizes the share-based compensation expense on a straight-line basis for each vesting tranche, when achievement\nof that tranche is considered probable.\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany evaluates the assumptions used to value stock awards on the grant date. If there are any modifications or cancellations of the\nunderlying unvested securities, the Company may be required to accelerate, increase or cancel any remaining unearned share-based compensation\nexpense.\n\n\n\nIncome\nTaxes\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany follows the provisions of FASB ASC 740,\nAccounting for Income Taxes\n(ASC 740). Under the asset and liability\nmethod of ASC 740, deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributed to differences between\nthe financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax base. Deferred tax assets and liabilities\nare measured using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected\nto be recovered or settled. Under ASC 740, the effect on deferred tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax rates is recognized in\nincome in the period that includes the enactment date. If it is more likely than not that some portion of a deferred tax asset will not\nbe realized, a valuation allowance is recognized.\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany recognizes a liability for uncertain tax positions. An uncertain tax position is defined as a position in a previously filed\ntax return or a position expected to be taken in a future tax return that is not based on clear and unambiguous tax law and that is reflected\nin measuring current or deferred income tax assets and liabilities for interim or annual periods. The Company may recognize the tax benefit\nfrom an uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not that the tax position will be sustained on examination by the taxing\nauthorities, based on the technical merits of the position. The Company measures the tax benefits recognized based on the largest benefit\nthat has a\ngreater than 50% likelihood\nof being realized upon ultimate resolution.\n\n\n\nAs\nof December 31, 2024 and 2023, there were no uncertain tax positions that resulted in any adjustment to the Companys provision\nfor income taxes. The Company recognizes interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits in its provision for income taxes.\nThe Company currently has no liabilities recorded for accrued interest or penalties related to uncertain tax provisions.\n\n\n\nNet\nLoss Per Common Share\n\n\n\nNet\nloss available to common stockholders is computed by dividing the net loss attributable to common stockholders by the weighted-average\nnumber of shares that were outstanding during the period. Diluted net loss available to common stockholders reflects the potential dilution\nthat could occur if securities or other contracts to acquire common stock were exercised or converted into common stock. Potentially\ndilutive securities are excluded from the diluted net loss available to common stockholders computation in loss periods as their effect\nwould be anti-dilutive.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n40\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNOTES\nTO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and 2023\n\n\n\n\nRecent\nAccounting Pronouncements\n\n\n\nIn\nNovember 2023, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update (ASU) 2023- 07,\nSegment Reporting (Topic 280): Improvements to Reportable Segment Disclosures\n(ASU\n2023-07), that requires disclosure of significant segment expenses that are regularly reviewed by the chief operating decision\nmaker and included within each reported measure of segment profit or loss. The standard also requires disclosure of the composition of\nother segment items included in the measure of segment profit or loss that are not separately disclosed. All disclosure requirements\nunder ASU 2023-07 are also required for public entities with a single reportable segment. The ASU is effective for the Companys\nAnnual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2024, and subsequent interim periods, with early adoption permitted.\nThe\nCompany adopted\nASU 2023-07 effective December 31, 2024 with additional disclosures detailed in\nthe subsequent notes.\n\n\n\nIn\nDecember 2023, the FASB issued ASU 2023-09,\nIncome Taxes (Topic 740): Improvements to Income Tax Disclosures\n.\nASU 2023-09 is intended to enhance the usefulness of income tax disclosures by requiring entities to disclose specific rate reconciliations,\namount of income taxes separate by federal and individual tax jurisdictions, and the amount of income (loss) from continuing operations\nbefore income tax expense (benefit) disaggregated between federal, state and foreign. ASU 2023-09 is effective for the Company for its\nfiscal year beginning January 1, 2025, with early adoption permitted. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of adopting this\nstandard on its consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.\n\n\n\nIn November 2024, the FASB issued ASU 2024-03,\nIncome Statement\n Reporting Comprehensive IncomeExpense Disaggregation Disclosures (Subtopic 220-40)\n. This ASU requires disclosure on\nan annual and interim basis, in the notes to the financial statements, of disaggregated information about specific categories underlying\ncertain income statement expense line items. The guidance is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2026, and interim\nperiods with annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2027, on a retrospective basis. The Company is currently evaluating\nthe impact of this standard on its consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.\n\n\n\nIn\nNovember 2024, the FASB issued ASU 2024-04,\nDebt  Debt with Conversion and Other Options (Subtopic 470-20)\n. This ASU clarifies\nthe requirements for determining whether certain settlements of convertible debt instruments should be accounted for as an induced conversion.\nASU 2024-04 is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2025, and interim reporting periods within those annual reporting\nperiods. Early adoption is permitted for all entities that have adopted the amendments in Update 2020-06. Adoption can be on a prospective\nor retrospective basis. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of this standard on its consolidated financial statements and\nrelated disclosures.\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany reviewed all other significant newly-issued accounting pronouncements and concluded that they either are not applicable to the\nCompanys operations or that no material effect is expected on its consolidated financial statements as a result of future adoption.\n\n\n', '_attributes': {'escape': 'true', 'id': 'Fact002254', 'name': 'us-gaap:SignificantAccountingPoliciesTextBlock'}, '_context': {'_contextref': 'From2024-01-012024-12-31_srt_ScenarioPreviouslyReportedMember', 'context_entity_identifier': '0000923601', 'context_entity_segment_explicitmember': 'srt:ScenarioPreviouslyReportedMember', 'context_period_startdate': '2024-01-01', 'context_period_enddate': '2024-12-31'}}

{'_val': 'Basis\nof Presentation\n\n\n\nThe\naccompanying consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the\nUnited States of America (GAAP).\n\n\n', '_attributes': {'escape': 'true', 'id': 'Fact002256', 'name': 'us-gaap:BasisOfAccountingPolicyPolicyTextBlock'}, '_context': {'_contextref': 'From2024-01-012024-12-31_srt_ScenarioPreviouslyReportedMember', 'context_entity_identifier': '0000923601', 'context_entity_segment_explicitmember': 'srt:ScenarioPreviouslyReportedMember', 'context_period_startdate': '2024-01-01', 'context_period_enddate': '2024-12-31'}}

{'_val': 'Principles\nof Consolidation\n\n\n\nThe\naccompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company, its wholly-owned subsidiaries SMCL, SMCM, SMH, Singing\nMachine, MICS Hospitality, MICS, MICS Hospitality Management, MICS NY, and its eighty percent (\n80\n%)-owned subsidiary, SemiCab\nHoldings. All intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation for all periods presented.\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany evaluates its business relationships with related parties to identify potential Variable Interest Entities (VIEs)\nunder the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Accounting Standards Codification (ASC) 810,\nConsolidation\n.\nThe Company will consolidate any VIE in which it is deemed to be the primary beneficiary of the VIE. The Company will be deemed to be\nthe primary beneficiary of the VIE if the Company has a controlling financial interest in the VIE. A controlling financial interest has\nthe following characteristics: (i) the power to direct the activities of the VIE that most significantly impact its economic performance;\nand (ii) the obligation to absorb losses of the VIE that could be significant to the VIE or the right to receive benefits from the VIE\nthat could be significant to the VIE. If both characteristics are met and, then the Company will consolidate that VIE into its consolidated\nfinancial statements.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n33\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNOTES\nTO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and 2023\n\n\n\nAs\nprescribed by ASC 810, if the Company holds a variable interest in an entity that is a VIE, but the Company is not the entitys primary\nbeneficiary, then the Company must disclose the methodology (e.g., significant judgments and assumptions made) that it used to determine\nthat it is not the primary beneficiary of the VIE. Additional information required includes information about the types of involvement\nconsidered significant, and those considered in the determination of whether the reporting entity is the primary beneficiary.\n\n\n\nFurthermore,\nif the Company provides or intends to provide financial or other support, whether explicitly or implicitly, to the VIE when not contractually\nrequired to, the Company must disclose the type and amount of the support along with the primary reasons for providing the support. Both\nqualitative and quantitative information about the Companys involvement with the VIE must be disclosed, including the nature,\npurpose, size, and activities of the VIE and how the VIE is financed.\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany determined that SMCB Solutions Private Limited, an Indian Company (SMCB), is a VIE because the Company\nprovides financial support to SMCB in the form of a loan agreement to fund SMCBs operations. The Company further determined that it is not the primary beneficiary of SMCB because the\nCompany does not have the power to direct or control SMCBs significant activities related to its business. Accordingly, the\nCompany has not consolidated SMCBs results of operations and financial position in its consolidated financial\nstatements.\n\n\n', '_attributes': {'escape': 'true', 'id': 'Fact002258', 'name': 'us-gaap:ConsolidationPolicyTextBlock'}, '_context': {'_contextref': 'From2024-01-012024-12-31_srt_ScenarioPreviouslyReportedMember', 'context_entity_identifier': '0000923601', 'context_entity_segment_explicitmember': 'srt:ScenarioPreviouslyReportedMember', 'context_period_startdate': '2024-01-01', 'context_period_enddate': '2024-12-31'}}

These estimates and\nassumptions affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses. Actual results could differ materially from these\nestimates. {'_val': 'Segment\nReporting\n\n\n\nPursuant\nto Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Accounting Standards Codification (ASC) Topic 280,\nSegment\nReporting\n(ASC 280), the Companys Chief Executive Officer serves as the Companys Chief Operating Decision\nMaker (CODM) for the purposes of ASC 280. The CODM concluded that the Company operates two reportable segments.\nOne\nsegment\nconsists of its SemiCab business and the other segment consists of its Singing Machine business. The CODM manages the Companys\noperations and business separately for each operating segment and uses net loss to allocate resources, making operating\ndecisions and evaluating financial performance. The CODM also uses net loss, along with non-financial inputs and qualitative\ninformation, to evaluate the Companys performance, establish compensation, monitor budget versus actual results, and decide the\nlevel of investment in various operating activities and other capital allocation activities.\nSee Note 15  Segment Information\nand Revenue Disaggregation  Segment Information\n.\n\n\n\n\nF-\n34\n\n\n\n\n\n\nALGORHYTHM\nHOLDINGS, INC AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNOTES\nTO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS\n\nDecember\n31, 2024 and 2023\n\n\n', '_attributes': {'escape': 'true', 'id': 'Fact002266', 'name': 'us-gaap:SegmentReportingPolicyPolicyTextBlock'}, '_context': {'_contextref': 'From2024-01-012024-12-31_srt_ScenarioPreviouslyReportedMember', 'context_entity_identifier': '0000923601', 'context_entity_segment_explicitmember': 'srt:ScenarioPreviouslyReportedMember', 'context_period_startdate': '2024-01-01', 'context_period_enddate': '2024-12-31'}}
